subject: Learning
title: Journaling for Learning
description: A quick, practical guide to Journaling for Learning.

hook.text: A student who journals after each study session learns 23% more than one who simply reviews notes.

buildup.text: Learning journals capture reflections: what was confusing, what clicked, and what needs revisiting.

discovery.text: Writing forces the brain to organize and articulate thoughtsâ€”transforming vague impressions into clear understanding.

twist.text: The journal doesn't need to be read by anyone. The act of writing is the metacognitive intervention.

climax.text: Over weeks, the journal becomes a map of your learning journeyâ€”patterns of strength and weakness emerge.

punchline.text: Write what you learned. The writing teaches you what you missed.

quiz.question: Why does journaling improve learning?
options: Writing forces the brain to organize thoughts and articulate understanding
